captions.text:
To make a laser, all you need to do is give
a big collection of atoms enough energy so

they're excited and ready to emit light. Once
one of them spontaneously emits a photon,

it'll stimulate some of the others to do so,
and you get a nice cascade of illumination.

But instead of letting all the light escape,
it's more powerful to trap it between two

mirrors and let it to bounce back and forth
through the atoms. All that passing light

will stimulate them to emit even more light,
and as long as you keep on re-exciting the

atoms, they're happy to go on emitting light
forever.

But why do the atoms emit light just because
another photon passes by? It's actually pretty
simple.

Imagine flipping two coins:
they can either be in the same state,
or in different states.

But photons aren't like coins - no matter
how hard you try, you can't tell one apart

from another. So in a "photon-flipping" experiment,
that means there's only one way for them to

be in different states, but two ways for them
to be in the same state. So they're more likely

to be in the same state, and in general, this
implies that photons always want to be like

other photons - to have the same phase, polarization,
and go in the same direction.

And what's more amazing is that if a solitary
photon passes by an excited atom that could

emit another photon, there's a good chance
it will emit one. Because the two photons

want be together - even BEFORE the second
one exists.

So once you have all these friendly photons
bouncing around between the mirrors, you can

just open up a little hole at the end and
let out a blinding stream of coherent light:
a laser beam.

To see lasers in action, check out this sweet
episode of "Smarter Every Day" showing a laser

you can stick your hand inside! They also
have a bunch of other cool science videos.

To see lasers in action, check out this episode
of showing a laser you can stick your hand

inside! And if you like it, he also has a
bunch of other cool science videos.

comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll Okay, so the video is wrong from 0:30 to 1:10. That's 
40 seconds. In about 40 seconds he has to explain why photons duplicate. 
What you said makes a lot of sense, but it will most likely cause a "tl, 
dr" as you said (and it did). I hope you don't mind, but I've tried to sum 
up what you said:

-Time direction is reversible: If an electric field (a photon hitting an 
electron of an atom) can cause the atom to absorb a photon, it can also 
cause it to *emit* one. This is called "stimulated emission" (la*SE*r). The 
emitted photon is identical to the incoming one.

-This can only happen in very specific circumstances (polarizations (spins) 
of the incoming light, relative phase and wavelength, angular momentum 
conservation, etc. Some of these are quite complicated). 
Only very specific photons get absorbed, so only very specific photons get 
"stimulatedly emitted".

-To make a laser work, there must be more excited atoms than atoms in their 
ground states, so that stimulated emission becomes more likely than 
absorption or spontaneous emission. This means that the gain medium (the 
medium where this happens) must be driven long and hard enough by light of 
the correct wavelength so that it will actually lase.
Then you let out some of the photons from the chamber and voilà, a laser.

Please correct me it got something wrong.
comments.author: Heulerado

comments.author: Henry Tan

comments.text:
+Videblu " I think the answer to my question lies in that big wall of text, 
or rather, the fact that you wrote a large block of text. "

Some things are just complicated. 

"Minutephysics explains things in a couple minutes, perhaps he 
over-simplifies a lot of them. "

No, his explanation was not an oversimplification. It was completely and 
utterly incorrect. He claimed lasing is something that photons just like to 
do because they're bosons and bosons entropically prefer to be in the same 
state. This is wrong, because if it were that way, all light would be 
lasers. 

No: gain media in lasers duplicate photons as a *dynamical* process. It's 
the special characteristics of the interaction between atoms and light that 
ensures photons are exactly duplicated. It's a property of the interaction, 
not of the photons, and trying to explain it in terms of the latter alone 
is guaranteed to give the wrong answer.

" to be helpful, and it seems to be an easier way to convey what you've 
just written."

The video is correct but it doesn't explain the same things as I just did. 
It asserts without proof that the interaction between light and atom 
exactly duplicates the photon. I tried to give you arguments as to *why* 
that's the case, because the explanation for the "why" given in this video 
is entirely wrong.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll I think the answer to my question lies in that big 
wall of text, or rather, the fact that you wrote a large block of text. 
Minutephysics explains things in a couple minutes, perhaps he 
over-simplifies a lot of them. That said, I did find this video 
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/54/Laser%2C_quantum_principle.ogv/Laser%2C_quantum_principle.ogv.480p.webm 
to be helpful, and it seems to be an easier way to convey what you've just 
written.
comments.author: Videblu

comments.text:
+Videblu "You write this on a lot of his videos."

Yes, because a lot of his videos are wrong. If you've seen my other posts, 
chances are you've seen my explanations also. This makes the flippant 
approach you just chose more than a little bit puzzling. 

As far as the subject of this video, I need only say that the entropic 
argument given in it is completely false. If it were true, any old 
flashlight would also be a laser since all photons in the same state would 
be entropically preferred.

However, that is very obviously not what happens, so the very simplistic 
"there are more states like this" entropy argument cannot be the answer. As 
such, you must discuss the phenomenon of stimulated emission -- that's what 
the SE in laSEr stands for. 

Stimulated emission is a process whereby an electron in an excited state, 
when hit by a photon, decays to a lower state while emitting an identical 
photon. The fact that the emitted photon is *identical* is the secret 
sauce: lasing cannot occur without this. Watching this video you might 
imagine that photons are emitted with all kinds of quantum numbers but that 
it's just *more likely* that the emitted photon has the same quantum 
numbers as the original because photons are bosons and there are more 
multiparticle boson states with all particles in the same state than 
otherwise. However, what is predicted by quantum theory is that (given 
certain approximations) incident photon get exactly duplicated with very 
high probability. 

This is a complicated dynamical fact that requires quantizing not only the 
atomic system, but the electromagnetic field, too. Now it turns out that 
the electromagnetic field is not often discussed in elementary courses in 
quantum mechanics, because photons are very complicated objects. In 
particular, they're always relativistic so you can't do "nonrelativistic" 
quantum mechanics with them. So no wavefunctions or Schrödinger equations 
or anything like that. 

I don't know of a simple way to explain this. Certainly the fact that 
photons *can* be in the same state is important: for fermions you can only 
have zero or one particles in the same state, so an "electron laser" 
(please do not confuse with a free electron laser) would be impossible. But 
it's not the whole story. You need an interaction that takes a state with 
one photon into a state with two identical photons. That is, the 
"duplication" is not a property of photons alone, as minutephysics 
suggested, but a property of the interaction. 

One piece of the puzzle may be understood quite easily. The laws of physics 
(well, most of them) are invariant under time reversal. If you replace t by 
-t in a valid equation and complex conjugate, you also get a valid 
equation. This means that if an electric field can cause an atomic 
transition that corresponds to *absorption* of a photon, then the *same* 
electric field can cause the transition in the opposite direction, 
accompanied by photon emission.

The piece that I can't elementarily explain is that these transitions only 
happen in very specific circumstances, which include specific polarizations 
(spins) of the incident light, as well as relative phase and wavelength. 
The net result is that, because only very specific photons get absorbed, 
only very specific photons get "stimulatedly emitted", which must be carbon 
copies of the original photon. Some of the "selection rules" that forbid or 
allow transitions have to do with rotational invariance -- photons have 
angular momenta, and interactions have to conserve total angular momentum. 
Others have to do with more complicated facts about representations of 
operators and symmetry groups in quantum mechanics. Others are a result of 
Schrödinger's equation when applied to the atomic system (not the photon, 
for which it's always inapplicable).

Then you must ensure that there is a population inversion, that is, that 
there are more atoms in their excited states than in their ground states so 
that stimulated emission becomes more likely than mere absorption. This 
means that the gain medium has been driven long and hard enough by light of 
the correct wavelength so that it will actually lase. What you want is for 
stimulated emission to happen often enough when compared to spontaneous 
emission (which gives random, incoherent light). Now you let out some of 
the photons from the chamber and voilà, coherent, polarized light.

Anywho, to tl;dr: the property that photons get duplicated is *not* a 
property of photons alone. It's a property of the interaction between 
photons and atomic systems. It's a *dynamical* fact, whereas the 
explanation given by minutephysics was merely kinematical/statistical.

comments.author: Steven Wang

comments.text:
Lasers with visible beams are really powerful. The powerful beams are 
partially absorbed by the particles in the air allowing it to be visible. 
Weaker lasers don't generally show up in normal air but if you shine it 
into fog, it has more particles to be absorbed by and thus is more visible. 
That's why lasers shows generally have fog machines.

comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
At the start of the video it said that "energy is added to excite the 
atoms."  In the excited state, when electrons get pumped into a higher 
orbit.  When in this state electrons eventually decay back to the ground 
state, and when they do so they emit a photon.  When a photon with the same 
frequency passes by, it encourages the electron to decay right away, which 
releases another photon that looks exactly the same as the one passing by. 
 This is what was meant by "want to be together".

Basically you excite the electrons, which emit photons as they decay.  Once 
photons are emitted they pick up clones of themselves, and those clones 
each pick up more clones etc.  Think of it as an amplifier for light.  Just 
add energy.

Minute Physics explains things the way they do because if they didn't then 
they would have to rename the channel to "Hour Physics" or longer.  The 
idea is to get people interested enough to be inspired to look up the 
details that couldn't possibly be squeezed into a minute of video (or even 
into a comment such as this one).

comments.author: Simran Wasu

comments.text:
+Jordan Shank I thought you might have since the correlation was so high, 
but I didn't wanna risk it. Glad we're on the same page :)

As far as your second question... I honestly don't know. I've grappled with 
the issue of "pop science" for a long time and I don't think I formed an 
opinion one way or the other. I guess in the name of honesty I should 
acknowledge the influence that good science communicators had on me and in 
my decision to pursue a scientific career. So I guess I can't complain 
about it too much. But I think that at least we should expect science 
communicators to maintain reasonably high standards in how they present 
their stuff.

One example I think is nice and you might've heard of was when Sixty 
Symbols did some videos about summing up the series 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + .... On 
the one hand, their approach wasn't rigorous and many viewers correctly 
called them out on it. On the other, their calculation was formally 
identical to the rigorous calculation, with some key conceptual steps 
omitted. Despite the shortcomings, the video and the discussions it 
generated were quite informative, regardless of educational level, and 
ultimately I believe it was an example of science (or math) communication 
done right. 

I guess if I had to give an answer it'd have to be something like "lying a 
little is okay, but not too much", which is exactly as vague as my opinion 
on the subject.

"Side note: From my own education, he's usually not wrong in most of his 
videos. This video seems to be an outlier than an accurate trend in Henry's 
scientific accuracy"

Yeah, I got to admit, my opinion of him is soured a little bit by some very 
wrong videos I've seen (notably the one on the Higgs boson). It's quite 
possible that most of his videos are right and I just tend to remember the 
bad apples.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll "D'oh"? Nah, I used the man-on-the-train situation for 
that very reason. Glad you caught that!

So, you're right. Henry's reasoning doesn't approximate reality in the 
slightest. (Side note: From my own education, he's usually not wrong in 
most of his videos. This video seems to be an outlier than an accurate 
trend in Henry's scientific accuracy.) But that raises a question I've seen 
other people approach in this video and others: namely, is it possible for 
his more... interesting ideas to be wrong in principle but right in 
practice?

Henry's videos may be factually incorrect, but they do expose a broad 
audience to interesting scientific phenomena. So, is it better that people 
watch these videos even if they're wrong? Or would it be better if people 
didn't watch these at all? I do think the former is preferable, since 
intrigued viewers might go on to learn more about the subject on their own, 
but that's just an opinion. I am curious to read your own, if you care to 
share.

I've been meaning to start my own physics channel, too, but I haven't found 
the time to write a script or set up a film area. Also, yeah, making videos 
interesting would be another problem to handle. Still love to try though.
comments.author: Jordan Shank

comments.text:
+Jordan Shank"By your logic, teachers shouldn't use this analogy because 
it's factually incorrect. "

That's not my logic at all. That's your supposition of what my logic is.

The explanation given by the teacher is the low energy (Newtonian) 
approximation to the full relativistic dynamics. It is the leading term in 
an asymptotic expansion in v/c. It's clearly appropriate to the problem at 
hand. Further, it's *more* appropriate than the full relativistic 
expression since any and all corrections that are of higher order in v/c 
get entirely swamped by experimental error and are unobservable, even in 
principle. Strictly speaking they can't be said to be there at all. So the 
Newtonian approximation is entirely justified, rigorous, and accurate.

In contrast, I know of a certain physics youtuber who dislikes Newtonian 
approximations... watch?v=IM630Z8lho8

D'oh!

The problem with the exposition in this video is not that it's 
"simplified", or even "outdated". It's *fictional*. It was never true, it 
never even resembled anything that could be construed as an explanation for 
a laser. You can easily see that this simple entropic argument cannot work 
by noting that if it were true you'd see lasing merely by placing on mirror 
in front of the other. This obviously doesn't happen. You *need* to 
understand stimulated emission and gain media. You *need* to understand 
population inversion. Population inversion is quite interesting by itself, 
since it leads to the subject of negative temperatures which are surprising 
and fascinating. 

A competent physics youtuber attempting to explain these concepts would 
have to find creative ways to make them accessible. Veritasium is typically 
very good at this. Minutephysics, on the other hand, tends to just make up 
whatever fictional explanation would sound sexy, even if it has only a 
passing resemblance to reality.

"You could even try making a video about it."

I've been meaning to try to start a physics channel, but honestly I don't 
think I have the competence or charisma to make videos that the average 
person would find interesting.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+gogerychwyrndrobwll There's a common analogy teachers use when teaching 
basic arithmetic. Imagine a man walking forward on a train that's also 
moving forward. What is the man's speed relative to the ground? According 
to the teacher, it's the man's speed on the train plus the train's speed on 
the ground. But that's false. Relativity tells us his speed is actually a 
little slower than that.

By your logic, teachers shouldn't use this analogy because it's factually 
incorrect. Their students would go into the world with the wrong idea about 
how the world works. It wouldn't matter that the students' understanding 
and the reality is off by mere trillionths of a m/s: wrong is wrong, period.

Maybe you're actually right. This video isn't accurate, and it's off from 
the reality by a lot more than the train situation is from reality. But 
unlike basic arithmetic, which has many possible analogies that a teacher 
could use, the physics of lasers is awfully complicated. This video shows 
what very well may be the simplest analogy possible that gets the basic 
idea of lasers across. It might be technically wrong, but a basic idea is 
better than no idea at all, right?

If you can think of a more accurate but equally simple analogy, I would 
honestly love to know it. I want to know more about lasers, too. You could 
even try making a video about it. If it's as entertaining and even more 
educational than these videos are, people will love to watch it.

It always baffles me how people think that an explanation being "accessible 
to a larger audience" makes it any less wrong. Uh, hello? If it's wrong, it 
should *not* be taught to a larger audience!

Leave the wrong, appealing bullshit to scifi writers. Science this ain't.

comments.text:
Not every material can be made into a laser. It isn't enough just to pump a 
bunch of energy into a substance. If you pump a bunch of energy into a 
solid, you won't get a laser beam. You will get a glowing, hot material 
that emits incoherent light across a broad spectrum (that is, white 
light). For a laser to work, the active medium must be able to absorb and 
store the photon. That is, the medium must have a fluorescent state. The 
wavelength at which the laser will produce laser light depends on the 
energy of the fluorescent state of the active medium. ﻿

comments.author: Justin Gould

comments.text:
for those who can't remember highschool science the atoms are excited by 
the amounts of quantified energy it can absorb in the form of a photon 
(quantified energies being the amounts of energy belonging to a jump or 
fall in levels of excitation). In the same way the atom can emit an equal 
amount of quantified energy in the form of a photon. These energies 
correspond to certain light wave lengths. So if you take a bunch of the 
same atoms which absorb and emit the same photons in exchanging the same 
quantified energy you'll get a bunch of the same colour of light (same 
wavelengths in the visible light spectrum). And this video explains how the 
light comes out in a beam. ﻿

comments.author: Babur R K

comments.text:
Yes, since your hand is probably warm it will always be emitting photons, 
just at very low frequencies we can't see. If you put your hand in a laser, 
most of it will be reflected, but the stuff that gets absorbed will go into 
your hand and heat it up. Since your hand is heating up it will start to 
increase in photon emission through the principle of black body radiation.
